link.title: 2011 newsmaker: Ryan Gosling

content.div:
Drive

Rating 4 (out of five)

Ryan Gosling didn't get an Oscar nod for his work in Blue Valentine last year, and, yet again, he got stiffed for a stand-out performance in Drive, a noirish thriller with a shocking-pink credit sequence. Don't think of it as genre confusion on the part of Bronson director Nicolas Winding Refn; think of it as Refn's stylish foreshadowing of the many jolts to come, as Gosling plays a Los Angeles stunt driver who moonlights as a highly paid getaway chauffeur. In the opening sequence of this beautifully crafted movie, which co-stars Carey Mulligan, Gosling's character is established as a meticulous risktaker who is the consummate professional. We like him immediately because he keeps his cool, but the longer the volcano lies dormant, the more certain we are of his eventual eruption. Special features include four featurettes.

The Thing

Rating 3 (out of five)

There's a whole lot of homage hulking around in The Thing. This remake of the seminal post-war science-fiction film about an extraterrestrial discovered in ice doesn't just nod to the nightmarish original from 1951; it gives a wink to the updated study of Other, Ridley Scott's classic from 1979, Alien.

You couldn't draw from two better sources, so even when this movie runs up against the wall of deja-vu and genre clich√©, it makes the most of the splatter.

In Time

Rating 2 (out of five)

Justin Timberlake has only got four minutes to save the world, but his alter ego, Will Salas, hardly has any time at all: In this alternative reality, money has been replaced by time as the central means of exchanging goods and services. Everyone has been genetically engineered to stop aging at 25, which opens up the possibility of immortality - as long as you can buy the minutes and the hours. Every human being comes into the world with 25, plus one year. However, because most parents have to borrow just to pay for their kids, that first year is usually all spent by the time they come of age and their clocks starts ticking. The resulting social map means the rich can store time in snappy little arm bracelets, ensuring they never have to run or rush anywhere, while the poor are constantly running and working just to live another day. It's a good social metaphor, but Timberlake lacks the acting chops to pull this off, and even the capable Amanda Seyfried looks exhausted, as she tries to make the dramatic scenes work. The ideas had merit, but the execution is draining. Special DVD features include deleted scenes and trailers.

To Kill a Mockingbird

Rating 5 (out of five)

An undeniable classic, this Robert Mulligan movie based on Harper Lee's novel takes us back in time, when a small-town lawyer in Depression-era America defends a man accused of rape. Atticus Finch (Gregory Peck) is one of the great screen heroes of all time, because he's not only a doting father; he embodies the brand of open-minded humanism America strives to represent. Even 50 years after its original theatrical release, this movie still stands up as one of the all-time greats, from just about every perspective. Peck picked up an Oscar for his performance, and Robert Duvall made his eerie screen debut as Boo Radley, all of which adds to the glorious folklore surrounding this shining piece of Americana. This 50-year anniversary Bluray edition is packaged as a book, with 44 pages of printed extras, including set photographs and script excerpts. Even bits and pieces of Peck's own script, complete with his own notes, is included in this thorough package A digital copy is also available via redemption code.
